facts.text: The case is Criminal Appeal No. 115 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 115 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Government Appeal No. 14 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 18, 1.959, of the Calcutta High Court in Government Appeal No. 14 of 1956.

facts.text: L. Anand, Ganganarayan Chandra, D. N. Mukherjee and P. K. Bose appeared for the appellant.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J. on April 12, 1962.

facts.text: A preliminary objection was taken that the certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) is not a proper certificate and should be cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: in which a preliminary objection has been taken that the certificate under Art. 134  1   e  is number a proper certificate and should therefore be cancelled.

facts.text: The appellant was tried for murder under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code in the court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore sitting with a jury.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was tried for murder under s. 302 of the lndian Penal Code in the companyrt of the Additional Sessions Judge at Alipore sitting with a jury.

facts.text: The jury returned a verdict of not guilty and the appellant was acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a verdict of number guilty and the appellant was acquitted.

facts.text: The State took an appeal to the High Court against the acquittal order.

anchor.surface_text: Against that order the State took an appeal to the High Court and the Division Bench found that there was mis- direction in the charge to the jury

facts.text: The Division Bench of the High Court found mis-direction in the charge to the jury.

anchor.surface_text: the Division Bench found that there was mis- direction in the charge to the jury and therefore after companysideration of the evidence it set aside the verdict of the jury,

facts.text: The Division Bench set aside the verdict of the jury, allowed the appeal and sentenced the appellant to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore after companysideration of the evidence it set aside the verdict of the jury, allowed the appeal and sentenced the appellant to imprisonment for life.

facts.text: The appellant applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 134  1   c  which was granted by another Division Bench of the Court which had number heard the appeal.

facts.text: The certificate was granted by another Division Bench of the High Court which had not heard the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: which was granted by another Division Bench of the Court which had number heard the appeal. Three points were urged before the Bench hearing the applioation for certificate

facts.text: Three points were urged by the appellant before the Bench hearing the certificate application.

anchor.surface_text: Three points were urged before the Bench hearing the applioation for certificate  1  that there was unusual delay in delivering the judgment

facts.text: Point 1: There was unusual delay in delivering the judgment and the Division Bench forgot to consider many questions of fact raised and argued before it.

anchor.surface_text: 1  that there was unusual delay in delivering the judgment and the Division Bench hearing the appeal forget to companysider many of the question of fact which were raised and argued before it.

facts.text: Point 2: The High Court had no power to substitute its own estimate of the evidence in an appeal against acquittal in a trial by jury.

anchor.surface_text: 3  that as a matter of fact there were numbersuch misdirection as caused a failure of justice or a mistrial and therefore the High Court was number entitled to examine the evidence.

facts.text: The High Court found no substance in points 2 and 3 but point 1 raised a question of importance.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges were of the opinion that there was numbersubstance in points Nos. 2 and 3 but the first points did raise a question of importance.

facts.text: The Supreme Court cancelled the certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court as not proper.

holdings.text: The certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court under Art. 134(1)(c) was not a proper certificate and must be cancelled.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the certificate granted by the Calcutta High Court was number a proper certificate and must be cancelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court granted certificate solely on unusual delay in judgment and possible omission to consider factual arguments raised, which are mere questions of fact; precedents (Haripada Dey, Sidheswar Ganguly) prohibit certifying mere factual issues as they do not involve complexities of law requiring Supreme Court interpretation; analogous to s.109(c) CPC requiring great public importance.

holdings.text: The mere ground of delay in delivering judgment is not a ground on which the High Court can certify a case to be fit for appeal to the Supreme Court under Art. 134(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: it was open to him to apply to this Court under Art. 136 but the mere ground of delay is number a ground on which the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even if delay led to points being lost sight of, it does not qualify; Art. 134(1)(c) requires certification of fitness involving legal complexities needing authoritative Supreme Court pronouncement, not factual or procedural grievances like delay.

holdings.text: A High Court is in error in granting a certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) on a mere question of fact and is not justified in passing such a question to the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: hi Haripada Dey v. The State of West Bengal 1  it was held that the High Court has numberjurisdiction to grant  1  1956 S.C. R 639, 641. a certificate under Art. 134  1   c  on a mere question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied precedents (Haripada Dey v. State of West Bengal; Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West Bengal) holding no jurisdiction to certify factual questions, converting Supreme Court into factual appeal court; certifying is strong act requiring substantial law issues.

holdings.text: It is not open to a High Court to grant a certificate of fitness under Art. 134(1)(c) merely because it believes the judgment of another Bench erred on certain facts.

anchor.surface_text: A mere ground of delay in giving a judgment does number, in our opinion, fall within the words fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court even if it is felt by the High Court that the delay might have led to omission to companysider arguments on questions of fact and law. It is number open to a High Court to give certificates of fitness under this clause merely

holdings.reasoning_summary: Even perceived factual errors or omissions due to delay do not justify certificate; must involve great or wide public importance akin to Privy Council interpretation of s.109(c) CPC.

holdings.text: There is no reason to grant special leave to appeal under Art. 136 in this case.

anchor.surface_text: We have heard companynsel for the appellant and we see numberreason to grant special leave in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After hearing counsel, despite printed record, no grounds warrant exercise of discretion for special leave.
